Award.AwardTitle: Would More Information Reduce Disagreement? Theory and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Disagreement is ubiquitous in society, often resulting in social conflict. Can disagreement on an issue be reduced by obtaining more information? The PI will investigate various questions related to this theme. The project beings by showing that while more information can sometimes reduce disagreement, it can also increase disagreement. The main focus is on when more information should be expected to reduce disagreement "on average".The second part of the project uses the results on disagreement to study problems in information economics.

The PI will develop models of persuasion, signaling, and markets with adverse selection to understand how an agent's information revelation is affected by the arrival of additional information. The additional information can be either exogenous or endogenously provided by other agents. Inter alia, new results will be obtained on how competition affects information provision.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project consisted of three parts: two concerned aspects of how new information affects disagreement between economic agents; the third tackled the effects of uncertainty about agents' information and preferences in signaling environments.

On the former topic, some of the PI's work has been summarized in a manuscript titled "A Theorem on Bayesian Updating with Applications to Communication Games". As the title suggests, there are two parts to the paper: one more foundational and one more applied. The foundational section identifies statistical conditions under which "more information" leads to "less average disagreement" among Bayesians. The applied section uses this result to provide new insights into two classes of communication games. The award has also supported PhD students' work on the topic of information and disagreement, including that at the forefront of one PhD dissertation.

On the latter topic, the PI's work has contributed to two main papers: one is "Muddled Information" (forthcoming in the Journal of Political Economy), and one is "What Kind of Central Bank Competence?" (forthcoming in Theoretical Economics). The first paper studied how the interaction of two kinds of aforementioned uncertainty affects market information when parameters of a signaling environment change, e.g., the signaling stakes (i.e., how keen agents are to signal). The paper identifies conditions under which there is less or more information about what the market cares about (e.g., the agents' information, rather than the agents' preferences) as stakes vary. The second paper builds on this framework in the context of central bank signaling through monetary policy. It shows that there can be a benefit to not knowing the central bank's preferences regarding inflation or output, because that mitigates signaling distortions that emerge from the central bank's incentive to boost output through monetary policy. One could hope that this research may contribute in some way to current thinking on central bank policy.
